DOCNAME: CASE OF TEBIETI MÜHAFIZE CEMIYYETI AND ISRAFILOV v. AZERBAIJAN
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 11;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Dean Spielmann;Elisabeth Steiner;Giorgio Malinverni;Khanlar Hajiyev;Sverre Erik Jebens
TEXT: CARDINAL . The ORG is a non - profit - making non - governmental organisation ( NGO ) , now dissolved , which was active DATE . The application was lodged by its former Chairman , PERSON , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . The ORG was registered by ORG on DATE and acquired the status of a legal entity .

CARDINAL . NORP Clause CARDINAL of the ORG ’s Charter defined it as an independent , charitable public organisation with voluntary membership , conducting its activities within the framework of the laws of GPE on public associations , other applicable laws and its own LAW .
CARDINAL . According to clause CARDINAL of the LAW , the main objects of the ORG were :

“ ... in the circumstances of the present - day environmental crisis , to develop the environmental culture and awareness of the various strata of the country ’s population , to organise a public movement for a clean environment in GPE , to give impetus to the process of effective resolution of environmental protection problems , and to strive permanently to promote the measures necessary to create a healthier environment . ”

CARDINAL . According to the LAW , the ORG ’s governing bodies consisted of the ORG ( the general assembly of members ) , ORG ( the management board elected by the general assembly for a fiveyear term ) , ORG ( a body of internal control elected by the general assembly for a DATE term ) , and various local bodies . Clause CARDINAL of the LAW provided that the ORG , as the general assembly of members , was the ORG ’s supreme governing body and would convene once DATE .
CARDINAL . Since the date of its establishment and ORG registration , and until DATE , the ORG had not convened a general assembly of its members .

CARDINAL . It appears that , on DATE , DATE after the ORG ’s State registration , ORG sent a letter to the ORG , noting that the latter had committed certain breaches of the domestic law and the ORG ’s own LAW . The exact content of that letter is not clear from the materials available in the case file .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG commenced an inspection of the ORG ’s activities .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG issued a warning to the ORG in accordance with section CARDINAL of the PERSON on nongovernmental organisations ( public associations and foundations ) of CARDINAL June CARDINAL ) , applicable at the material time ( “ the NGO Act ” ) . The ORG stated that the ORG ’s activities did not comply with the requirements of its own LAW and the domestic law . It was noted that a general assembly of the ORG ’s members had not been convened within the DATE period specified in its own LAW . Moreover , in any event , this provision of the LAW was itself incompatible with the domestic law , as section CARDINAL.CARDINAL of LAW required that the supreme governing body of a public association – the general assembly of members – was to be convened at least once DATE . ORG requested that , within DATE , the ORG take measures to remedy the above - mentioned breach and inform ORG measures taken .

CARDINAL . NORP In reply , PERSON informed the Ministry that , in fact , a general assembly of members had taken place on DATE . It appears that , among other things , the ORG ’s general assembly decided to establish a working group in order to bring the Association ’s Charter into conformity with the current legislation .

CARDINAL . Having examined the documents relating to the general assembly meeting of CARDINAL DATE , on DATE ORG issued a new warning to the ORG ( which constituted a second warning issued in DATE ) . It noted that the general assembly of CARDINAL DATE had been convened in violation of numerous provisions of the domestic law . ORG noted , inter alia , that not all members of the ORG had been properly informed about the general assembly and thus had been unable to participate in it , and that the ORG ’s local branches had not been equally represented at the assembly . Generally , the current membership records had not been properly kept and it was impossible to determine the exact number and identity of members . Local branches of the ORG had not held any regular local assemblies of members and , in fact , functioned as regional offices directly governed by the head office in an administrative and hierarchical manner , whereas in a genuine public association ordinary members should be able to directly participate in its management . ORG again demanded that , within DATE , information be submitted as to the steps taken to remedy these breaches .
CARDINAL . It appears that the ORG disagreed with the above findings in its correspondence with ORG and took no action in response to this second warning .

CARDINAL . Finally , on DATE the ORG issued a third warning , stating that it had not received any information from the ORG as to compliance with the prior CARDINAL warnings . In addition to reiterating the remarks contained in the prior warnings , the Ministry noted that the ORG also engaged in an activity prohibited by law . Specifically , the domestic law ( namely , LAW , the PERSON on environmental protection of DATE and the PERSON on entrepreneurial activity of DATE ) prohibited public associations from interfering with the activities of private businesses . In this connection , the ORG noted :

“ However , contrary to these legal requirements , the ORG ... attempts to collect money from ORG organs and commercial organisations in the guise of membership fees , regularly conducts [ unlawful ] inspections at economic enterprises and draws up [ environmental compliance ] reports , and engages in other illegal acts interfering with the rights of entrepreneurs ... ”
CARDINAL . As it had done previously , the Ministry demanded that , within DATE , the ORG submit information as to the steps taken to remedy the situation . The ORG did not react .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE ORG lodged an action with ORG , seeking an order for dissolution of the ORG . The ORG , represented by PERSON , lodged a counterclaim , contending that the ORG ’s warnings had been unlawful and unsubstantiated .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the ORG ’s counterclaim and granted the ORG ’s request , ordering the ORG ’s dissolution .

CARDINAL . Specifically , in respect of the ORG ’s request for dissolution , the court heard oral submissions by the ORG ’s members and the officials of ORG , reviewed the content of the ORG ’s CARDINAL warning letters issued in DATE and examined the correspondence between the ORG and the ORG . The court also examined CARDINAL internal reports by various officials of ORG concerning the results of the inspection of the activities of the ORG ’s various local branches . According to these reports , most of the inspected branches had not held regular local assemblies of members and had not maintained proper records of members and membership fees . CARDINAL of these reports stated that , according to “ information obtained ” during the inspection , the ORG ’s branch in the GPE region carried out illegal environmental inspections and engaged in other illegal activities .

CARDINAL . Based on the above materials , the court found that , despite the early warning issued on DATE ( the content of which was not specified in the judgment ) , the ORG had continued to commit breaches of domestic law on an even more systematic basis , which had led to the issuance by ORG of the CARDINAL warning letters in DATE . The court noted that LAW had not been brought into compliance with the domestic law on public associations , which required that a general assembly of members be held no less than once DATE . In any event , even the DATE period for convening a general assembly , as required by LAW , had not been complied with . The court further found that the ORG ’s findings concerning numerous irregularities during the general assembly meeting of CARDINAL DATE , as well as breaches of law in the general functioning of the ORG , constituted a basis on which to dissolve the ORG for systematic failure to comply with the domestic law .

CARDINAL . Furthermore , again based on the above - mentioned oral testimonies of the ORG officials and their inspection reports , the court noted that the ORG had frequently overstepped the limits of the scope of its activities as defined in its LAW and permitted by law , by interfering with the competence of the relevant ORG authorities . In particular , it was noted that the ORG ’s local branches had attempted to carry out unlawful environmental inspections on the premises of various ORG and commercial enterprises and collect membership fees from them , issued reports on these enterprises’ compliance with environmental standards , and engaged in other actions interfering with the activities of commercial entities . The court found that , by engaging in such actions , the ORG had violated the rights of other persons and attempted to misappropriate powers of a ORG regulating authority .

CARDINAL . The court further noted that , in accordance with LAW , the issuance of CARDINAL warnings by ORG constituted a basis for an association ’s dissolution if the latter did not take any measures to remedy the shortcomings in its activities . The court therefore ordered that the ORG be dissolved .

CARDINAL . The ORG appealed , claiming that the provisions of LAW were vague and imprecise , giving the Ministry a wide discretion to interfere with public associations’ activities and to issue warnings even for minor irregularities in their activities . The ORG also argued that ORG factual findings concerning its activities had been incorrect and unsupported by any evidence .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal and upheld ORG judgment .
CARDINAL . By a final decision of DATE , ORG upheld the lower courts’ judgments .
CARDINAL . The ORG ’s State registration certificate was revoked and the ORG was dissolved .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the NGO Act provides :
“ QUANTITY . This PERSON regulates the relations concerning the establishment and functioning of public associations and foundations .
CARDINAL . The definition of ‘ non - governmental organisation’ in this PERSON includes public associations and foundations .

CARDINAL . This PERSON determines the rules for the establishment , activity , reorganisation and dissolution of non - governmental organisations , as well as their functioning , management , and relations with government bodies .

CARDINAL . This PERSON does not apply to political parties , trade unions , religious organisations , local self - administration authorities and non - governmental organisations which are regulated by other laws . ”

CARDINAL . Under LAW , a public association is defined as an NGO established on the initiative of several individuals and/or legal entities associated on the basis of common interests in pursuing the objectives set out in the association ’s by - laws , which does not engage in profit - making as a primary aim of its activity and which does not distribute any profit between its members .

CARDINAL . Chapter IV ( sections CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) regulates issues related to the activities and property of NGOs . In particular , under section CARDINAL , an NGO may engage in any type of activity which is not prohibited by the laws of GPE and which is not contrary to the aims of the organisation as set out in its charter .

CARDINAL . Chapter V ( sections DATE ) contains rules on the management of NGOs . Section CARDINAL provides that the internal structure of a public association , the powers of its governing bodies , their formation procedure and term of office and the rules on decision - making and representing the association shall be regulated by the public association ’s charter , subject to the conditions set out in LAW and other relevant legal provisions . In particular , the supreme governing body of a public association is the general assembly of members , to be convened not less than once a year , upon the initiative of the associations ’s executive body , CARDINAL of its founders or CARDINAL of its members ( sections CARDINAL - CARDINAL.CARDINAL ) . The general assembly decides upon , inter alia , the following issues : ( CARDINAL ) adoption of and amendments to the association ’s charter ; ( CARDINAL ) use of the association ’s property ; ( CARDINAL ) election of the association ’s other governing bodies and early termination of their office ; and ( CARDINAL ) approval of the DATE report , among other publications ( section CARDINAL ) . The founders and members of the public association must be informed of the date and place of the general assembly DATE in advance . Amendments to the association ’s charter may be made only if the quorum of CARDINAL of the association members is present . Decisions are adopted by a majority of votes of the participating members . Each member has CARDINAL vote ( section CARDINAL ) . It is required to keep written TIME of the general assembly , which shall be signed by the assembly ’s president and secretary and , if necessary , distributed to all members ( section CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provides :
“ CARDINAL . A non - governmental organisation that breaches the requirements of this PERSON shall be liable in accordance with the laws of GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG If a non - governmental organisation commits actions incompatible with the objectives of this PERSON , the relevant executive authority [ ORG ] may issue a written warning to the organisation and give an instruction to remedy such breaches .
CARDINAL . A non - governmental organisation may judicially challenge such warning or instruction .

CARDINAL . ORG If a non - governmental organisation receives , within DATE , CARDINAL written warnings or instructions to remedy the breaches of law , such organisation may be dissolved pursuant to a court order . ”

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the PERSON on environmental protection of DATE provides , inter alia , that the carrying out of environmental monitoring and audits is within the competence of the relevant ORG authorities . Sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the PERSON on environmental protection define the rights and obligations of NGOs in the field of environmental protection . The essence of the NGOs’ rights , within the meaning of these provisions , is the civic defence of environmental rights , encouraging public debate on environmental issues and alerting the relevant ORG regulatory authorities to any environmental hazard or breach of the applicable environmental standards . The range of NGOs’ rights in this field does not include a right to conduct formal environmental inspections or enforce relevant environmental norms or standards .

CARDINAL . Likewise , section CARDINAL of the PERSON on ecological safety of DATE vests rights in NGOs , inter alia , to make proposals on ecological safety to the relevant ORG authorities and alert the latter to breaches of environmental laws . NGOs are not vested with a right to enforce environmental laws .

DATE . CARDINAL . No external intervention in the running of NGOs should take place unless a serious breach of the legal requirements applicable to NGOs has been established or is reasonably believed to be imminent .

CARDINAL . In most instances , the appropriate sanction against NGOs for breach of the legal requirements applicable to them ( including those concerning the acquisition of legal personality ) should merely be the requirement to rectify their affairs and/or the imposition of an administrative , civil or criminal penalty on them and/or any individuals directly responsible . Penalties should be based on the law in force and observe the principle of proportionality .

CARDINAL . The termination of an NGO ... should only be ordered by a court where there is compelling evidence that the grounds specified in paragraph CARDINAL ... above have been met . Such an order should be subject to prompt appeal . ”

CARDINAL . A comparative study of the relevant legislation of CARDINAL out of CARDINAL member ORG shows that an NGO can be membership - based or non - membership - based and can take a variety of legal forms applicable in the domestic legal order , such as an association , foundation , trust , charity or even company . A key factor in determining the level of scrutiny and control that an NGO will be subjected to is whether the body concerned is legally incorporated and enjoys legal personality . Normally , unincorporated associations enjoy a much wider scope of selfmanagement and are not interfered with unless they conduct activities which are illegal or prejudicial to public order . Legally incorporated NGOs , on the other hand , are often subject to more narrowly delimited rules and may be dissolved or face other sanctions in the event of non - compliance .

CARDINAL . It appears that in a number of GPE an NGO can , in certain circumstances , be dissolved either , specifically , for failure to conduct its internal management in accordance with the requirements of domestic law or , more generally , for failure to comply with its own charter . Countries within this category include : ( i ) GPE , where an association can be dissolved by a decision of a competent public authority if , inter alia , it exceeds its field of activity or if it no longer fulfils its own statutory rules ; ( ii ) GPE , where foundations , endowment funds and public benefit corporations can be dissolved by a court for failure to comply with their charter or the domestic law ( however , associations can not be dissolved for failure to conduct their internal management ) ; ( iii ) GPE , where a court may on the basis of an action brought by the relevant public authority or an association member dissolve an association if it acts substantially against the law or substantially against the purpose defined for it in its rules ; ( iv ) GPE , where the courts may declare the dissolution of a civil society organisation if it has failed to operate for DATE , or the number of its members is permanently below the number determined by law ; ( v ) GPE , where the competent governmental authorities may dissolve foundations in the event that they are not conducted in a lawful manner and in conformity with their by - laws ; ( vi ) GPE , where associations may be dissolved for failure to comply with the objectives which they have assumed , or if they have gravely contravened their constitutive statute or the law ; and foundations can be dissolved if they are no longer able to pursue the object for which they were created ; ( vii ) GPE , where a voluntary organisation may be struck off the register of voluntary organisations and/or issued with a suspension order potentially permanently suspending all or part of its activities , if the organisation in question is not complying with the provisions of its statute or the relevant domestic law ; ( viii ) the GPE , where a regional court can dissolve an association or foundation , inter alia , if its statutes do not fulfil the requirements of the law or if it acts substantially contrary to its own ORG ; ( ix ) GPE , where the courts can , in situations where associations are found to be acting contrary to the law or infringing the provisions of their own charter , order their dissolution ; ( x ) GPE , where the relevant law provides that an association ’s failure to convene its general assembly or board of directors for DATE results in its de jure dissolution ; ( xi ) GPE , where an association may be dissolved if it repeatedly and seriously violates the requirements of the applicable domestic law ; ( PERSON ) GPE , where courts can decide to dissolve non - profit organisations , foundations , non - investment funds and associations for contraventions of the applicable domestic law as regards their internal management ; and ( xiii ) GPE , where the Civil Code provides that associations can be dissolved for , inter alia , failure to compose the internal bodies required by law , hold their first general assembly meetings within the time - limits prescribed by law or to hold subsequent general assembly meetings regularly .
